name: quicktips
description: Display quick tips within VS Code.

commands.title: QuickTips: Display a useful tip about VS Code and its installed extensions

quickTips.tip: VS Code extension developer? You can add tips for your own extension
You can quickly switch between files with Ctrl+Tab
You can toggle the sidebar visibility with the Ctrl+Shift+B
You can move the current line up or down with Alt+Up and Alt+Down respectively.
Select all occurences of current selection with Ctrl+Shift+L
Select all occurences of current word with Ctrl+F2
You can toggle comments for current line with Ctrl+/
Open the version-control sidebar with Ctrl+Shift+G
Open the debug sidebar with Ctrl+Shift+D
Open the file explorer sidebar with Ctrl+Shift+E
Open the search sidebar with Ctrl+Shift+F
Toggle console output visibility with Ctrl+Shift+U
Delete the current line with Ctrl+Shift+K
The VS Marketplace contains a more user-friendly list of the available extensions
You can split the active editor into two with Ctrl+Shift+\
You can switch between editor views with Ctrl (Mac: 'Cmd') key and 1, 2, or 3.
Drag and drop title area of an editor to reposition or resize it
Type Ctrl+P to quickly search and open a file by its name
Use the files.exclude setting to configure rules for hiding files and folders from the explorer
Regular expressions are supported in the search boxes
You can configure advanced search options by typing Ctrl+Shift+J
From the Explorer you can right-click on a folder and select Find in Folder to search inside a folder only
Ctrl+G will let you navigate to a specific line in a file
When using Ctrl+P, type ? to get a list of available commands you can execute from here
Hold Ctrl and press Tab to view a list of all files that have been opened since VS Code was launched
You can open any file by its name when you type Ctrl+P
Set the file encoding globally or per workspace by using the files.encoding setting.
Click on the encoding in the status bar to reopen or save the active file with a different encoding
The window.openInNewWindow setting controls if files should open in a new window instead of reusing an existing VS Code instance
The window.reopenFolders setting tells VS Code how to restore the opened windows of your previous session
You can quickly look for extension updates by using the Extensions: Show Outdated Extensions dropdown
You can jump to the matching bracket with Ctrl+Shift+]
You can add secondary cursors with Alt+Click. Each cursor operates independently based on the context it sits in.
Use Ctrl+Alt+Up to insert cursors below or above
Ctrl+D selects the word at the cursor, or the next occurrence of the current selection
Ctrl+K Ctrl+D moves the last added cursor to next occurrence of the current selection
Quickly shrink or expand the selection with Shift+Alt+Left and Shift+Alt+Right (applies to all languages)
You can always manually trigger completion with Ctrl+Space
You can type only the upper case letters of a method name to limit the suggestions. For example, `wl` will quickly bring up WriteLine.
The 24x7 IntelliSense can be configured via the editor.quickSuggestions and editor.suggestOnTriggerCharacters settings
By pressing Tab, you can expand Emmet abbreviations in HTML, Razor, CSS, Less, Sass, XML or Jade
If a language supports it, you can go to the definition of a symbol by pressing F12
If you press Ctrl and hover over a symbol, a preview of the declaration will appear
You can jump to the definition with Ctrl+Click or open the definition to the side with Ctrl+Alt+Click
If you opened a new editor window, you can go back to the previous editor with Ctrl+Alt+Left
You can navigate symbols inside a file with Ctrl+Shift+O. By typing : the symbols will be grouped by category.
In C# and in TypeScript, you can jump to a symbol across files with Ctrl+T.
If your folder is a Git repo, each change will make useful annotations be added to the gutter and to the overview ruler
When you execute a Reference Search (via Shift+F12), or a Peek Definition (via Alt+F12), the result is embedded inline
You can make quick edits right and navigate between different references in the peeked editor
Clicking on the peeked editor filename or double-clicking in the result list will open the reference in the outer editor
For languages that support it, the hover will show useful information, such as types of symbols
With C#, directly invoke the Find References action by clicking on inline reference information
With C#, Reference information can be turned on or off through the editor.referenceInfos setting
With TypeScript and C#, you can quickly rename symbol across files with F2
You can click on the summary or press Ctrl+Shift+M to see a list of all current errors and warnings
Press F8 or Shift+F8 to loop through errors or warnings in the current file
